issue.title: Feature Request: private to protected scope changes

repository.name: yii2
repository.description: Yii 2: The Fast, Secure and Professional PHP Framework

body: you can just override `populate()` method for this instead of `createModels()` with the same effect.
In general, we have private methods to allow refactoring internals without the risk of breaking backwards compatibility.
sorry, I missed the part of using the config in afterFind().
Just pinging. Is there going to be any resolution to this issue?

within your inheritance usecase, I dont see why the afterFind() event won't do in combination with overriding populate() (in which you set & unset the event).

If you can convince me of that, we will make it protected.
I do not understand how do you mean to do that. Could you provide an example which does the same as requested in https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/issues/12015#issue-167455731 ?
Have you tried a solution with the 'after find' event yet? https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/blob/master/framework/db/BaseActiveRecord.php#L901

Please explain how that would work? :)

So that I can use this:

``` php
ActiveRecord::find()->configure([ 
'scenario' => 'something',
'property' => 'somethingElse'
])->all();
```

And **all** found models will have their **scenario and property already set** when `afterFind()` gets called?
If I understood correctly I should set the after find event on each of those models and then remove it afterwards? Please tell me **which function** should I extend in `ActiveQuery` to attach that event so that it gets called when `parent::afterFind()` is executed?

The only way your solution would work is that I set a behavior to every model I need this to be done and set model configuration inside that behavior statically which:
1. Is not configurable outside of the same model (unless you expect me to set configuration statically?)
2. It would defeat the purpose of simple extension which would be done easily if just one function goes to protected.

The ONLY solution which I know which keeps all of this is that I make a hack by using `indexBy` and passing my own function in there which does the configuration and that is a horrible implementation IMO.

Ok as I see that would work. But that seems also more like a hack than a good solution, and if its not coded and maintained correctly, it may cause many problems. 

Also I cannot believe that I should make a workaround like this instead of doing a simple extension of one function.

No this is not a good solution.

I acknowledge and respect your eagerness for desiring the best solution. In the future we will put effort in improving the architecture around ActiveQuery & ActiveRecord. For now you already have 2 possible and valid ways to solve your problem:
- By extending ActiveRecord and set default parameters
- By using Events

thanks for sharing your thoughts

issue.title: Multiple update: set scenario

repository.name: yii2
repository.description: Yii 2: The Fast, Secure and Professional PHP Framework

issue.body:
if (Yii::$app->request->isPost) {

    foreach ($models as $model) {
        $model->scenario = 'massUpdate';
    }
    if (Model::loadMultiple($models,Yii::$app->request->post()) && Model::validateMultiple($models)) {
        foreach ($models as $model) {
            $model->save(false);
        }
        return $this->refresh();
    }
}
I worry about this code. Unnecessary loop. 
    foreach ($models as $model) {
        $model->scenario = 'massUpdate';
    }
Maybe existence other way? If not, I offer add new parameter! 
Model::loadMultiple($models,Yii::$app->request->post(),'massUpdate');

body:
It seems quite rude to cut someone off like this without giving a chance to say something about it. So I will leave this issue with these thoughts:
1. Your workaround won't work correctly for use cases when the same model will be loaded inside `afterFind()`, as is in case of recursive parent-child loading since children will get the same configuration because of the global event. Or in any other use case when the same model will be loaded in `afterFind()`. So that is something to keep in mind when using this.
2. Keeping methods private in an open source project is not a good idea in the long run IMHO. I understand your idea of making people do better implementation with what they have while making code more robust to future changes but as you see, you need a perfect foresight for this and an ability to see the future. Aside from that, there are currently some things in Yii that are impossible to do because of this, and the time I spend "convincing" that some change is needed is the time taken from doing actual work with Yii. Not to mention all of the other integration checks and tests needed to be passed until the next version/revision is released. Your time would be better spent on making this framework even better than trying to code around changes to allow maximum compatibility with other people code. You do not want to make another Wordpress I hope :)

Anyways, thanks for clarification. I guess I have no other choice than to go with this workaround. Hope things will get different as Yii progresses. :)

We are very pleased to see your effort to convince us of the necessity. Dont feel bad about your topic been closed. Sometimes we close subjects in order to not to repeat ourselves. I will create a PR today which solves your issue.
